recommendations: Pique Turn is a movement performed in the passé position while turning to the inside and  usually done in a series.. For practicing Pique Turn as a/an intermediate performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Plie variations: Try doing grand plies in first, second, and fifth positions, as well as demi-plies with various arm positions. , Releves variations: Single-leg, double-legs in first, second and fifth positions, releve passé, Arabesque balances, Spotting exercises: Doing half-turns or full turns with a focus on spotting, Flexibility stretching for 10 repetitions on each for 20 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Begin with your feet in first position, heels touching and toes pointing outward. Evenly distribute the weight between your feet and core muscles for balance and control., Prepare for the turn by lifting your back foot into a pique position, bringing it to the back of your supporting ankle. Hold this position firmly and securely, and make sure your weight is centered over your supporting foot., Use your supporting leg to initiate the turn by pushing off the ground and lifting your pique foot into a passe position in front of your knee. Keep your core muscles engaged and your arms in a comfortable position for balance and control., As you turn, pivot on your supporting leg and bring your pique foot around to the front, pointing your toes and keeping your leg straight. Keep your eyes focused on a fixed point in front of you to help with spotting, and use your core muscles to help you maintain your balance and control throughout the turn.            , Complete the turn by landing on your supporting leg with your pique foot still in front of your knee. for 10 repetitions on each for 20 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on stability, additional exercises could include Plank holds: Start with a standard plank hold for 30 seconds, then progress to side plank holds and plank variations such as mountain climbers and plank jacks., Single-leg balance: Practice balancing on one leg, with arms in different positions to challenge yourself. You can also try adding in arm or leg movements while maintaining your balance., Bosu ball balance: Use a Bosu ball to work on your stability and balance. Stand on the flat side of the ball and try different balance exercises, such as standing on one leg, squatting, or doing lunges..

Pique Turn is a movement performed in the passé position while turning to the inside and  usually done in a series.. For practicing Pique Turn as a/an amateur performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Plies with 10 repetitions, Tendus with 10 repetition on each side, Passe releves with 10 repetitions on each side for 10 repetitions on each for 20 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Begin with your feet in first position, heels touching and toes pointing outward., Transfer your weight to your left foot and lift your right foot off the ground, pointing your toe and bringing it to the back of your left ankle., Push off your left foot and lift your right leg into a passé position, bringing your foot to the front of your left knee., As you turn, pivot on your left foot and bring your right leg around to the front in a pique position., As you complete the turn, land on your right foot with your left foot in a pique position. for 10 repetitions on each for 20 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on stability, additional exercises could include Plank holds: Start with a standard plank hold for 30 seconds, then progress to side plank holds and plank variations such as mountain climbers and plank jacks., Single-leg balance: Practice balancing on one leg, with arms in different positions to challenge yourself. You can also try adding in arm or leg movements while maintaining your balance., Bosu ball balance: Use a Bosu ball to work on your stability and balance. Stand on the flat side of the ball and try different balance exercises, such as standing on one leg, squatting, or doing lunges..

Jazz Contraction is a contraction of the muscles in the back of the legs, which is used to create a higher jump.. For practicing Jazz Contraction as a/an advanced performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Pilates teaser, Yoga wheel pose, Dance floor work for 10 repetitions for 20 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart., Bend knees, lowering into deep plié., Curve spine forward, engaging core., Drop head, maintaining neck alignment., Incorporate dynamic full-body movements. for 10 repetitions for 20 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on stability, additional exercises could include Plank holds, Single-leg balance, Bosu ball balance.
